Why French politics can't cope without an absolute majority
subhead: While most European countries have learned to manage their fragmented parliaments, France has failed to adapt. The 'fait majoritaire,' the political dominance of a president backed by a parliamentary majority, has so deeply shaped politics since 1962 that lawmakers have been unable to envision governments built on a base of negotiation and compromise.

title: On the border with Ukraine, Polish residents live in fear: 'When I heard that explosion, I thought, that's it, that's war'
subhead: In the east of the country, along the Ukrainian and Belarusian borders, where Russian drones crashed on September 10, residents live in constant fear of war.
byline: By Jakub Iwaniuk (Slawatycze and Wyryki (Poland), special correspondent)

title: When sex workers on content platforms open up to their parents
subhead: Since the Covid-19 pandemic, pornographic content platforms have been booming, attracting young creators – mainly women – who turn to sex work for the money and independence it offers. Some choose to speak to their parents about it. Those conversations can either produce distance or bring them closer together.

title: What is the purpose of central bank independence and who does it serve?
subhead: By launching a harsh attack on the Federal Reserve, US President Donald Trump tried to exert control over an independent institution. But should these central banks really be left solely in the hands of experts and technicians? Economist Jézabel Couppey-Soubeyran explores the issue in her column.

byline: By Arnaud Leparmentier (Saint George, (Utah) special correspondent)

title: Israeli intelligence admits Iran's nuclear program has not been destroyed
subhead: Israeli officials have recently provided French authorities with their own assessment of the airstrikes that targeted Tehran's nuclear arsenal in June. This information is particularly valuable to France after American intelligence agencies have halted all cooperation with their European partners regarding the Iranian nuclear program.

title: Nan Goldin, photographer: 'The camera gave me a voice, and a way in'
subhead: 'I wouldn't be here if...' Each week, Le Monde asks a public figure about a decisive moment in their life. The American photographer reflects on her sister's suicide, which changed her view of the world.
